captions.text:
Welcome to the Preseason Spotlight. In
this video, we're going to introduce

the biggest changes coming for the
jungle, objectives, and items in the

2015 Preseason. You can think of this
as a high-level overview – if you

want more details, hit up the preseason
microsite and the patch notes.

Before we get to the krugs and
gromps of what’s changing, let’s

talk about the big focus for 2015:
strategic diversity. In other

words, it's giving you more paths
to victory so your in-game

decisions matter just as much
as the champions that you pick.

Alright, jungle. Important thing here is
jungle diversity. Sounds an awful lot

like last year’s preseason, but we’re
taking a different approach for 2015.

We've got new item paths, Smite’s got
some shiny upgrades, and we're making

monsters tougher to better differentiate
between your Warwicks and your Rammi.
Also there's a crab.

First, spirit items are gone.
Hunter’s Machete now upgrades

into four new items, each changing
Smite in a different way.

Stalker’s Blade is
gank-focused, letting you

smite enemy champions
for damage and a slow.

Poacher’s Knife is for the
counterjunglers, giving you bonuses

when Smiting down camps on the
enemy side of the jungle.

Skirmisher’s Sabre is a dueling upgrade.
Smite an opponent

and gain a combat buff against
them for a few seconds.

Finally, Ranger’s Trailblazer is
your farm-focused pickup, turning

your Smite into an AoE and
restoring health and mana on use.

You can also buy enchantments, ensuring
you get the end-game stats you need.

Be sure to read up on those because
we’re not explaining them here.

We’re also adding bonuses for smiting monsters.
Smite the raptors

to get a true-sight buff when you’re spotted by a ward.
Murkwolves recruit a ghost that provides

vision, Gromp hooks you up with a poisonous thornmail,
Krugs let you stun monsters every few attacks,

and smiting red or blue restores health or mana.
You can probably figure out which is which.

Finally, under the jungle category
we’ve got your new favorite camp:

the Rift Scuttler. This tanky
crustacean actively avoids combat,

but if you bring him down he gives
vision of either the Baron or

Dragon pit and a speed shrine for
all of your teammates. Thanks crab.

Next up, let’s talk about objectives.
They’re changing. Strategically.

First, turrets. There are new
regenerating shields on the inner turret

which spread to nearby allies, providing
extra safety against sieging.

And yes, what you’re seeing,
that’s a laser. This is

a new change for the inhibitor
turret, and it slows

and causes whoever it hits
to deal less damage to

help deal with those pesky
split-pushing Jaxes.

Baron's a badass now instead of
a lategame snack. Not only will

you have to actually pay attention
when taking down Baron but,

when you finally do, Baron buff
now lets you recall twice as

fast while also giving your
nearby minions super siege power.
Dragon and turrets have always had similar rewards -- gold. To create strategic differences,

Dragon now no longer gives gold but grants a
permanent stacking buff on kill. The buffs go up as

your team secures more Dragons, adding up to the
giga stack bonus. Kill five dragons for your team

and you’re going to hit like a monster truck
wearing a suit of larger, cooler monster trucks.

This year we focused on strategic
items that benefit your

team more than just giving you
an individual pile of stats.

First, there are new Elixirs. Ruin gives
bonus damage to towers and boosts your split

pushing, Sorcery gives ability power and true
damage on hit, Iron buffs your size, and boosts

the movement speed of any ally who follows you, and
Wrath gives attack damage and some life steal.

Each of these is tailored to your
specific needs at any point in the game.

Second, meet Righteous Glory. Stats aside,
Righteous Glory’s active gives a big

movement speed bonus when running toward
those those super annoying disengage teams.

After a few seconds, you’ll
emit a massive slowing

pulse that hits all
nearby enemy champions.

Sadly, the movement speed
bonus does not scale
up with how annoying the enemy team is.
In short, the philosophy we’re pursuing is around the ways you look to win
and the paths to victory your team can take.
And this is just the beginning.
Preseason is a time when we can experiment heavily with League to bring it to a better place,
and there are a lot of changes we haven’t mentioned in the video.
Be sure to check out the microsite and the patch notes for more details but, for now,
this is your Preseason spotlight signing off.

comments.author: Viorel Daniel Borceanu

comments.text:
I appreciate that they try to keep it fresh every year, but most of the 
time, when big changes are made, most champions don't get accordingly 
balanced towards them. They mostly do that throughout the year, and by the 
time they finish tweaking up at least 70% of champs, they roll out a new 
season, change everything again and then it starts aaaaaall over. 

I hate to bring up Dota 2 in conversations about League (seeing how most 
people react to that) but when a huge update comes out there, pretty much 
all the heroes and most items are re-tweaked accordingly. Of course, they 
don't roll out patches every week, yes, but they give time to people to 
adjust and savor the new stuff. League is always rushing somewhere, 
constantly changing stuff for no reason, really and doing a half-assed job 
at it and it's a shame.
I'll probably try it out when it will come out, but I'm getting really 
tired of changing things for the sake of changing them.
If it's not broken, don't fix it. If it is, do it all-out and release one 
big patch. That's my 5 cents. ﻿
